It’s interesting to see that amidst a lot of scepticism around GraphQL, new projects like Sourcehut will still choose it and clearly argue for it.

https://sourcehut.org/blog/2020-06-10-how-graphql-will-shape-the-alpha

Do you want some flashbacks to the horrors of trigonometry? Here’s fizz buzz in cosines.

Dependency cooldowns were the first thing we instituted after tj-actions forced us to hash-pin all the GitHub actions we pulled in. Glad the industry has now also caught up.

https://blog.yossarian.net/2025/11/21/We-should-all-be-using-dependency-cooldowns

AI sales targets are down. Github Actions prices are going up. Most of their software is second tier at best. Microsoft is still, Microsoft.

“RDS goes down too. And when it does, you’re still the one getting paged, you just have fewer tools to fix the problem.”

item.title: Window Managers
item.description:
Window managers have become a bit of a special interest of mine. After being a Rectangle user for most of my macOS life, I tried out Amethyst and Yabai and finally settled on Aerospace.

Aerospace is nice and stable and gets the job done of me never having to manually layout my windows again. I have a couple of layouts that I mainly use and its built-in Spaces are much faster (and therefore much more useful) than the ones macOS gives you.

“That this sounds radical – that one might believe in a democracy that creates laws, affords companies economic freedom within those laws, and enforces those laws against companies that choose to violate them – says much about our divisive times.”

https://bcantrill.dtrace.org/2023/11/26/what-punch-cards-teach-us-about-ai-risk

Good to have explained this explicitly why mathematics is such an essential component of programming. People without an inclination for this kind of abstract mathematical thinking often are poor and chaotic programmers.

https://the-nerve-blog.ghost.io/to-be-a-better-programmer-write-little-proofs-in-your-head

Many chefs I know get upset at me when I tell them this. But this is the truth: If you can’t cook everything you make in a microwave thats a skill issue.

Can’t argue with that.

https://www.colincornaby.me/2025/08/in-the-future-all-food-will-be-cooked-in-a-microwave-and-if-you-cant-deal-with-that-then-you-need-to-get-out-of-the-kitchen/

Predictions are a nice business because at some point they will be true.

https://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/deutsche-bank-grim-warning-ai-industry

Lots of respect for the people who spend years pushing something like a standardised Python lock file. It’s crucial but invisible work.

https://snarky.ca/why-it-took-4-years-to-get-a-lock-files-specification

I still haven’t upgraded to the new iOS and seeing these reports, I’m not sure whether I should.

https://www.nngroup.com/articles/liquid-glass

When people say that Kubernetes is complicated, this is the stuff they mean. As far as I can tell, there’s no way to play this complexity game reliably, so the only reasonable way through would be not to play.

https://blog.amberwolf.com/blog/2025/september/kubernetes_namespace_boundaries

https://www.theregister.com/2025/10/20/aws_outage_amazon_brain_drain_corey_quinn

What I always say: “Premature abstraction is the root of all evil.”

Rust has its fair share of this but it’s nowhere near as bad as in a language like Typescript.

https://daymare.net/blogs/everbody-so-creative

The harder the constraint, the more dangerous it is.

It will surprise nobody that I too will err on the side of “allow nulls and check for them in your application code”. It’s cheaper to maintain and cheaper to evolve and those are the only things you have to optimize for until you reach massive scale.

https://www.seangoedecke.com/invalid-states

We really should have Starlark as a configuration language everywhere because it’s very expressive and easy to read/understand. Instead we’re stuck with ever increasing piles of YAML and obscure configuration formats that nobody wants to deal with.

https://openrun.dev/blog/starlark

That’s a deep dive through layers and layers of abstraction from Rust to LLVM intrinsics to instruction expansion at the processor level.

It’s fascinating stuff but as much as I like Rust, I still have no idea at what point I would ever need such a thing.

https://questdb.com/blog/rust-fetch-max-compiler-journey

https://lukeplant.me.uk/blog/posts/breaking-provably-correct-leftpad

https://marcosh.github.io/post/2025/10/07/the-mondrian-introduction-to-functional-optics.html

It’s always been my feeling that TLS has unacceptable collateral damage in how it breaks the web for normal people. That’s considered a bit of a crank opinion, but I’m definitely not the only person who feels that way.

https://michael.orlitzky.com/articles/lets_not_encrypt.xhtml

The Bitter Lesson is an interesting concept. Stuffing the prompt runs into diminishing returns pretty quickly but on the other hand, getting your AI to play well with tools is challenging.

https://blog.nilenso.com/blog/2025/10/14/bitter-lesson-applied-ai

The marketing that DHH does for projects was always bad, disingenuous and annoying.

So Rails users were OK with DHH back when he was pushing their shitty web framework of choice. But now all of a sudden they draw the line. He didn’t change that much really.

https://crimier.github.io/posts/Framework-Omarchy/

https://tekin.co.uk/2025/09/the-ruby-community-has-a-dhh-problem

An explanation of the AT Protocol and how it could be the open layer that allows everybody to own their data.

https://overreacted.io/open-social

Every programming language has to strike a balance when it comes to abstraction and none of them get it right. Rust is written in a way that is often too abstract for the things that you want to do with it.

https://corrode.dev/blog/simple

Github is over and many leading edge developers have already moved off or are seriously considering it.

https://www.mistys-internet.website/blog/blog/2024/07/12/github-is-starting-to-feel-like-legacy-software

We should have more histories of software. There are lots of things that have been tried out and learned which if they aren’t captured will disappear entirely.

https://mergify.com/blog/the-origin-story-of-merge-queues

The guide to sqlite query planning and tuning is cool, but what’s even better is that this kind of scale and optimisations are possible at all with sqlite.

https://emschwartz.me/subtleties-of-sqlite-indexes

The situation described here where AI writes 90% of the code is almost entirely the same as how any software engineer works already. The only thing that’s changing is that instead of code you’re writing instructions to the LLM.

https://lucumr.pocoo.org/2025/9/29/90-percent

Gleam is truly a dream of a programming language. I’m looking forward to launch my project and do more with it.

Litestar is an interesting addition to the list of Python microframeworks with a lot going for it.

https://www.b-list.org/weblog/2025/aug/06/litestar

We’re seeing increasingly more posts about jj coming out and I can’t repeat enough that it is totally worth switching away from git.

https://maddie.wtf/posts/2025-07-21-jujutsu-for-busy-devs

Every time I have to cross-compile something (usually in Rust to run on the cloud somewhere) it’s always rather confusing to figure out the correct target triples. Weird that something that’s this fundamental is documented this poorly.

https://mcyoung.xyz/2025/04/14/target-triples

The write-up how Bun can be so fast is a good exploration in all the things that computers are good at now. Machines and our networks have gotten much faster and much more parallel which influences what an optimal approach to building software is now.

We don’t use Bun but I’m happy to see that even on these benchmarks pnpm is no slouch. You could do much worse than that.

An excellent Jujutsu reference covering most of the basic operations you will need.

https://justinpombrio.net/src/jj-cheat-sheet.pdf

The AWS CEO doing not much more than stating the obvious when it comes to AI and software engineering.

https://www.theregister.com/2025/08/21/aws_ceo_entry_level_jobs_opinion

A good description of how if software engineering was setup for speed of iteration we would have entirely different environments than we have now. Nobody is really opposed to speed, but nobody really wants it either so we end up with bloated development and bloated results that are the worst of all compromises.

https://inessential.com/2025/08/28/easy-app-writing.html

Congratulations to That Browser Company on what must be a stellar exit for them.

No idea what Atlassian can do with this because it is the place where technology goes to die.

https://www.cnbc.com/2025/09/04/atlassian-the-browser-company-deal.html

This may sound harsh, but it’s a lot fairer than they deserve: “But since the product is no longer jumping exponentially in capabilities, they will need to fall back on proper product development if they want to be competitive. A very cool and simple introduction into Lean and what makes it interesting. I’m not sure exactly what draws people in this direction but it’s cool to see the progress that’s being made here.

And there sure is a lot of bad things to go around, here’s one list drafted by Julia Evans.

https://jvns.ca/blog/2023/11/01/confusing-git-terminology

The Javascript Date class is so criminally bad, that you will have a better score if you give random answers than if you try to reason about it.

https://jsdate.wtf

item.title: Keeping Claude in check with Jujutsu
item.description:
I’ve found it very useful to use jj to continuously and automatically snapshot the changes that Claude makes. This way if it does anything that I didn’t want, it’s incredibly easy to undo it and still keep a clean history.

Here’s what my hackathon project looks like in the gg client after several days of on and off development.

You can have Claude do these steps as well. It’s pretty good at jj describe even if a bit verbose. And in most cases it could also do jj new before every change, something that I forget occasionally.

At scale you will be slapped in the face by this tail or that all the time. It’s a clear and simple argument to rehabilitate the mean as the measurement we should be looking at.

https://brooker.co.za/blog/2021/04/19/latency.html

Complaining about the Cloud has become fashionable and it’s an easy thing to do. What’s not so easy is to create strategic room to maneuver.

I enjoyed these pieces by Will Kelly in part also because they are very glib. They connect because they contain a kernel of truth. The real way to get out of the cloud is indeed: “Real ops maturity. Procurement leverage. The discipline to say “no” to vendor convenience.” That’s the real work for anybody who’s interested in doing it.

One of the best ways to learn anything (including Git) is to make the entire thing yourself from scratch. Obsess over the details.

https://drew.silcock.dev/blog/artisanal-git

For the many people who may not be intimately familiar with the workings of Turing machines, this visual and interactive guide should get them up to speed really nicely.

It’s mostly just the mechanics of the machine and doesn’t go into the more fun and formal parts such as reductions and proofs. But it’s a start.

https://samwho.dev/turing-machines

A very informative write-up of how you would squeeze out the last bits of performance out of a Rust port. Not sure if I’d ever apply this but I’m happy enough that I can mostly follow along.

https://ohadravid.github.io/posts/2025-05-rav1d-faster

To hearken back to the previous comparison of Java versus compiled languages, AWS has a case here where a naive rewrite of their JVM database in Rust created massive performance wins.

At this point, you need to be asking yourself: Why would anybody ever write a database in Java?

https://www.allthingsdistributed.com/2025/05/just-make-it-scale-an-aurora-dsql-story.html

It’s relevant to my interests to read how others have massively scaled the systems we use. Discord has a solid write-up here of how to deal with Elastic Search.

Which is all good and well, but I’m a bit sad that we have so much systems software written in Java which in some cases works well (Kafka, Spring) but in other cases is a bit of a slog (Elastic, Cassandra). There are Rust/C++ search stores out there which out of the box beat a Java solution 2-5x on speed and 1/10th on memory usage. Those are numbers that make a huge difference at scale.

A twofer on software estimation that also tallies with my intuition. People are really great at estimating the median which is impossible to communicate to people without deep intuition for software engineering and statistics.

It makes total sense as a guideline to multiply your initial guess x1.6 for the mean, x5 for the 95th percentile and x10 for the 99th percentile. This is also why deadlines are irrelevant and counterproductive in software engineering. There are much better ways to achieve the same goals.

I fully agree with Paolo Scanferla here that very complex typing (“hyper-typing”) is an impediment to get anything done but besides the technical aspects, here are some ratchets here that are very pernicious.

  1. Creating very complex typing is hard to argue against (“But don’t you see how this is safer?”) and simplicity rarely wins in group programming environments. You’re essentially arguing against somebody who’s posturing as being very clever (“It’s very easy and safe this way.”).
  2. Once you lose the initial argument and the complexity gets in, it’s impossible to get out again. It will only expand in your code base and make everything it touches also overly complex. Getting this out is several orders of magnitude more work than getting it in and can only be done by (the very few) people who understand the entire thing. Those people have made an excellent manoeuvre for their own job security and against everybody else’s productivity.
  3. This kind of typing is not incidental. The very design of Typescript and its increasingly more and more complex type system is meant to enable this. Language features that are there will always be used and regularly misused. It’s near impossible to guard against that. That’s why I consider any language with an overly expressive type system to be suspect (and this is why Go is good). Liking Typescript is a code smell on the person.

https://pscanf.com/s/341

Using the same Github account for work that you also use to do anything and everything else with is not particularly secure. That’s why I split my presence on the platform, but getting everything to work that way has been somewhat annoying.

I found this guide by Rahul Pandey that’s been a huge help in how to take a lot of the pain out of it.

We use reservoir sampling a lot day to day and here’s a great visual explanation of how this algorithm does this seemingly impossible task.

https://samwho.dev/reservoir-sampling

Thorsten Ball keeps writing bangers such as this speed run how to write a AI coding agent.

It always feels to me that Cursor is mostly a balancing act of hacking a collaborative editor into the VSCode codebase (poorly) more than it is chockfull of LLM based innovations.

https://ampcode.com/how-to-build-an-agent

Solid and sober career advice in the current landscape.

https://lethain.com/career-advice-2025

I could quote this entire article by Dan North:

It takes daily resolve and good habits. It takes effort and deliberate practice to train yourself to ‘unsee’ the general case; to not reach for a library first ‘because it is only adding a single dependency’; to not prematurely abstract or DRY code because reasons; to not over-invest in a component because we have blanket coding standards with arbitrary rules like percentage of test coverage; to go back and stabilise that component you sketched to see if it would work, and it did; to excise that component you sketched that did not work out.

Something that I also need to try. The rise of overlay networks that can create private networks and make all your devices and servers internet addressable is a huge convenience.

https://blog.6nok.org/tailscale-is-pretty-useful/

Here’s a topic over at Lobsters of what a bunch of software engineers would like to see programmed out in the world. Every ask gets a bunch of suggestions of things out there that could fill that gap.

Three hundred plus replies in this is a deep view of how much still remains unexplored in the software engineering problem and solution space.

https://lobste.rs/s/btjtkr/what_software_do_you_dream_about_do_not

Should managers be in the code? Yes, absolutely. Should managers write code? Maybe, but it also depends on what you mean by writing code.

A good answer to the age old question. I ship more code right now than I ever have.

https://theengineeringmanager.substack.com/p/should-managers-still-code

A thought provoking attack on SQL with a bunch of pointers and hints as to what could come next. I’m pretty competent with SQL but that is exactly the point where you should become interested in what the limitations are and in what situations it makes sense to break out of the paradigm.

https://www.scattered-thoughts.net/writing/against-sql

I’m not a huge fan of these “best programmer” lists, but this list was better than most that I have seen.

https://endler.dev/2025/best-programmers

The amount of positive things happening around Python packaging and performance is really cool to see. Here’s a way to compile Python directly to Webassembly and get much better performance.

https://lukasz.langa.pl/f37aa97a-9ea3-4aeb-b6a0-9daeea5a7505

I’ve never used a tool that supports interdiff code reviews, but seeing it described here, it makes intuitive sense and I would love to have this. Instead we are–as is pretty much everybody else–stuck on Github.

All of those things listen above are in support of your primary goal: ensuring that you are getting shit done. You cannot get shit done to a world-class level by leaving all of the details to other people.

A great argument for being in the details as a manager and a lot of examples of what that can mean for your org and situation.

https://www.theengineeringmanager.com/managing-managers/being-in-the-details/

item.title: Scrubbing Secrets with jj
item.description:
Last time I talked about how I use jj for small code changes while being interrupted all the time as a manager. This time we’ll be using it in anger.

Open Sourcing a Project

I’ve been long overdue to open source my little side project Cuppings. This is always annoying because pretty much every project will have a bunch of sensitive stuff checked in at some point. In this case the repository contains a Google Maps API key (as well as the entire database, but that’s a different story) which is something I definitely do not want to share with the internet ((Github may have an integration with Google for this so the API key may be disabled as soon as the repo is public anyway, but who knows.)).

Running a public website these days means staving off attacks from every LLM company in the world trying to get your data (legally or illegally).

https://status.sr.ht/issues/2025-03-17-git.sr.ht-llms
Type level programming in Typescript has been driven to the point of pure absurdity by implementing a DOOM runtime on it to play the game with.

We liked to pretend that it was possible to use American cloud providers with any measure of sovereignty, but that pretence is going to drop very soon now. Not sure what the alternatives are, but everybody should be planning for some drastic changes here.

https://berthub.eu/articles/posts/you-can-no-longer-base-your-government-and-society-on-us-clouds

A good overview of how Git developers configure git for themselves with a bunch of settings that should be the default for everybody but which will take ages to be rolled out. You should copy most of these into your own config.

https://blog.gitbutler.com/how-git-core-devs-configure-git

I think this critique of Flamework is a bit rich coming from the author of Flask with its global request object. But there is a point in being able to iterate really quickly, it’s even better to be able to work crudely without creating a disastrous unmaintainable mess.

There is a difference between writing terrible code well or writing beautiful code poorly.

Chronicle of how you make a hit game. Balatro is amazing even if I ripped through it in a couple of days.

https://localthunk.com/blog/balatro-timeline-3aarh

https://www.herostrat.us/posts/learning-the-hardest-problem-in-computer-science

Here’s a good article about platform teams that I got to read an early draft of. I can say from my own experience that all of these traps are very easy to go into. Be aware and prioritize ruthlessly what works and what doesn’t work.

https://serce.me/posts/2025-01-07-six-sins-of-platform-teams

item.title: Using jj as a manager
item.description:
I think when people ask what’s so great about jj they tend to go deep into things such as mega-merge strategies and stacked PRs. These things are cool, no doubt, but jj can be useful starting from the very small.

In my case as a manager I commit a lot of small stuff, documentation updates, nits, fixes (and also larger bits of code). I got this down to be pretty fast using all the git aliases available.

I can relate to this because I’m using Cursor to write a bit of Gleam where it’s usually off entirely because this is such a small language.

It would be annoying maybe if LLMs got us into a place where literally everything becomes a React+Tailwind application but so far I don’t see a huge risk that that will happen.

What is available and what is easy does of course influence what becomes popular, but nothing new there.

A lot has been made of this talk about Egoless Engineering but I can say that for me it came at the exactly right time. In our platform team we got to the point mentioned in the talk and are now working on #3: Empower Everybody Else.

https://egoless.engineering/#50

Obsidian is a knowledge worker’s lightsaber. It’s indispensable for any kind of serious work and it is now free to use.

https://obsidian.md/blog/free-for-work

Rare to see an actual apples-to-apples comparison of databases like this. Postgres comes out ahead versus Sqlite but as always, it depends.

https://www.twilio.com/en-us/blog/sqlite-postgresql-complicated

Another funny relic from the depths of version control: the Octopus Merge

https://www.freblogg.com/git-octopus-merge

This is the way “A Pattern Language” intended we should talk about patterns: applied and without making things more complicated. Patterns should simplify and be grasped immediately.

https://grantslatton.com/design-patterns

Filing this away for future reference when at some point we’ll want to get out of managed Kubernetes.

https://bilbof.com/posts/kubernetes-on-hetzner

A very good explanation about “object soup” and how Rust is uniquely poorly suited to model problems in that way. It pins down a very fundamental issue that people coming from an object oriented background run into all the time and offers a helpful solution.

https://jacko.io/object_soup.html

Quanta’s write-ups of math discoveries are always enjoyable to read. In this case an undergraduate (!) figured out something new about hash tables and how fast they can be. Not sure yet when this will be shipped in code, but still it’s a pretty amazing discovery.

https://www.quantamagazine.org/undergraduate-upends-a-40-year-old-data-science-conjecture-20250210/

Wild to see the materials that go into making a single inference machine for private use. At scale this stuff will of course be more efficient, but still the main components will be more or less the same.

https://ewintr.nl/posts/2025/building-a-personal-private-ai-computer-on-a-budget

We’ve revived our tech blog and will be sharing a bunch of stuff around our AI process and what it means to be an “AI first” company. Here’s an in-depth first piece about what it takes to develop a successful real life product with LLMs.

https://choco.com/us/stories/life-at-choco/scaling-ai-applications-with-llms

LLMs are fundamentally matching the patterns they’ve seen, and their abilities are constrained by mathematical boundaries. Embedding tricks and chain-of-thought prompting simply extends their ability to do more sophisticated pattern matching. The mathematical results imply that you can always find compositional tasks whose complexity lies beyond a given system’s abilities.

item.title: December Adventure
item.description:
So I felt I couldn’t really bring myself to do Advent of Code this year since I have more than enough other things to do (and watch and play) and with work and the kids, it’s always pretty miserable to keep up.

I saw this thing called December Adventure though and that fits in nicely with my current push to release a major update for Cuppings. If I’m going to be programming until late this month, then I’d prefer it to be on something that I can release.

Seeing if I can move from Arc to Vivaldi but there are half a dozen radical improvements in Arc that *make* the experience. It just shows how much innovation and solid thinking was packed in all of that frivolous design.

Vivaldi on the other hand has a million settings which mostly show that nobody knows wat this app is supposed to be doing. There are entire note taking apps and e-mail clients in there but none of them fun or nice to use.

Chuffed by the strength of my team that we have most of the easy decisions from these Node.js pillars in place and we are making headway on all of them to the extent that’s appropriate for us.

https://www.platformatichq.com/node-principles

I read this piece about CORS and the only thing I can tell you about it is that I hate web security.

https://jakearchibald.com/2021/cors

Nicolas from All About Berlin has done so much to make living in this administrative nightmare bearable for people. It’s a very clear example of what kind of 10-100x improvements are there to be had.

https://nicolasbouliane.com/projects/all-about-berlin

I painstakingly built a bespoke Rust web application to host the Cuppings venue data and to add Google place_ids to almost 2000 Foursquare location. That’s been done for a while now but now we have the announcement of Foursquare open sourcing their location dataset.

That has two direct consequences for me:

  • I was going to scrub the Foursquare data out of the database as a clean-up but that’s something I won’t do for now. In fact, I may recode the venues so I have ids in both worlds.
  • I was toying around with the idea of building a next generation Foursquare/Dopplr on top of atproto which is something that I think is a lot more feasible now.

https://simonwillison.net/2024/Nov/20/foursquare-open-source-places/

https://buttondown.com/carlton/archive/thoughts-on-djangos-core

Reading these database migration stories is usually interesting, but what I found especially noteworthy here is that all of the Django features they used to make it easy for themselves have been in there for more than a decade.

That’s the kind of maturity that maybe makes a technology like that not that appealing to work with for new developers but it is also a maturity that lets you get real work done.

For example, there cannot be two parallel flows with mutable access to a value. Nor can there be a flow that borrows a value while there is no flow that owns the value.

Freeing the memory twice could have catastrophic consequences.

If you just want to leave some valid value behind, std::mem::take 2 is a good candidate. It is equivalent to std::mem::replace(&mut value, Default::default()); it moves value out from behind the mutable reference but leaves a new, default value for the type in its place.

So I had some code very similar to the following that wouldn’t compile and me with my old Python head was a bit surprised why this was the case. It was a bit more complicated to figure it out in my example but this simplified version makes it pretty clear.

trait SomeTrait {}

impl SomeTrait for u8 {}
impl SomeTrait for u16 {}

fn function() -> impl SomeTrait {
    if true {
        0u8
    } else {
        0u16
    }
}

Why did I think it would work? Because both types implement the same trait, it’ll come down to the same thing in the end and that should be fine, right? I think that’s Python talking.

item.title: A small contribution to apple/swift
item.description:
I saw a starter task fly by in the Swift Weekly Brief and jumped on it. Now it turns out that the Swift project has a util directory full of various Python scripts that perform various tasks including cloning and building the project.

One of those python scripts needed to print out a message if somebody calls it without the –clone parameter. If you don’t do that, it doesn’t clone all the repositories that you need to be able to build the project. I did some path fiddling and testing against a sample of directories that should be present and there is PR #12856 that got merged into the project (and got mentioned in the next Brief).
